reviewText: Phillip Marlowe, Raymond Chandler's classic noir hard-boiled private detective forever literarily associated with Los Angeles and its means streets is right at home here in his search for the inevitable `missing woman' (`dame' for the non-politically correct types) of an ex-convict who will not take no for an answer. And a `missing woman" who wants to stay missing and will not take no for an answer. There is plenty of sparse but function dialogue, physical action and a couple of plot twists, particularly around the identity of the above-mentioned `dame' that caught me off guard.  Give me those background oil derricks churning out the wealth while looking for Rusty Regan in Big Sleep or the run down stucco flats in pursue of Moose's Velma in Farewell, My Lovely any day. As always with Chandler you get high literature in a plebian package. Robert Mitchum is just the right actor at that point in his career where his profile and manner match the aging world-weary P.I. who has been around the block but who still seeks justice, whatever that may be and however it can be had.

reviewText: Not going to pay high price for this used DVD.NEEDS TO BE RELEASED. Robert Mitchum is the best Marlowe since Bogart (and in some regards as good). Supporting cast is excellent too, including small role by legendary noir novelist jim Thompson.It demands a state-of-the art re-release.

reviewText: Raymond Chandler (1888-1959) became a writer at age 45 and his first novel, "The Big Sleep", appeared in 1939. Chandler's characters and plots represented a change from the prevailing models (e.g., Sherlock Holmes, Charlie Chan) and was aligned with Dashiell Hammett "hard broiled" approach. In fact, Chandler considered Hammett "the ace performer", and FWIW Hammett's Sam Spade from "The Maltese Falcon" is considered the holy grail of detectives.Chandler's character, Philip Marlowe, first appeared on screen in "Murder My Sweet" in 1944, although previous films had been adapted from Chandler's works (e.g., "The Falcon Takes Over"). Marlowe was played by several actors - Dick Powell ("Murder My Sweet"), George Sanders ("The Falcon Takes Over"), Lloyd Nolan ("Time to Kill"), Humphrey Bogart ("The Big Sleep"), Robert Montgomery ("Lady in the Lake" and "The Brasher Doubloon"), James Garner ("Marlowe"), and Elliott Gould ("the Long Goodbye"). Robert Mitchum plays him in this film and also in "The Big Sleep" (1978).Robert Mitchum (1917-97) received his only Oscar nomination for "The Story of GI Joe", but movie fans know that Mitchum was a terrific actor who deserved far more acknowledgement, but his "bad boy" persona undoubtedly interfered. Mitchum's work in films like "The Night of the Hunter" (1955) and "Cape Fear" (1962) is ranked by AFI as among the top 100 villains of all time. I liked him best as the drunken sheriff in "El Dorado" (1966).IMHO - Mitchum is the best person for Philip Marlowe, but I think he is perhaps 10 or 15 years too old for this film. He's much better suited for "The Yakuza" which came out in the same year.Mitchum is supported by an all star cast of characters including John Ireland and Harry dean Stanton as detectives, Charlotte Rampling as a love interest, and Anthony Zerbe, Jack O'Halloran, and Sylvester Stallone.Handsome John Ireland (1914-92) was nominated for an Oscar for "All the King's Men" (1949) and won a Golden Boot in 1989 for his many western films like "Red River" (1948), "I Shot Jesse James" (1949), "Little Big Horn" (19561), and "The Bushwackers" (1951).Harry Dean Stanton (1926) is the cult hero of films like "Repo Man" (1984) and "Paris, Texas" (1984). Stanton's philosophy of acting - Usually, I just play myself. Whatever psychological traumas or conflicts I'm going through at the time I try to put into the role."Sinewy Charlotte Rampling (1946) was nominated 4 times for a French Oscar and 6 times for a European Film Award. American audiences will remember her best from "Zardoz" (1974) and "The Verdict" (1982). I think her best role was in "The Night Porter" (1974).Husky voiced Sylvia Miles (1932) was nominated for an Oscar for her role in this film; her second nomination following "Midnight Cowboy" (1969). She is great but on screen far too little.Wall- eyed Anthony Zerbe (1936) plays a charming villain. He is best remembered as the villain in such films as "The Omega Man" (1971) and "License to Kill" (1989). According to his own count, one year he dispatched 163 people on screen. His philosophy - For every cold-blooded killer on your screen, there's a little old lady somewhere who calls him 'sonny.' "Big Jack O'Halloran (1943) plays Moose, one of Mitchum's clients. A former heavyweight boxing contender, this was his film debut. He's best known for his role as the super villain from Krypton from "Superman 2" (1980).The film is directed by Dick Richards (1936) who was nominated for an Oscar and a BAFTA as producer for "Tootsie" (1982), the only other film he produced. As a director he made only 7 films including "The Culpepper Cattle Co." (1972) and "March or Die" (1977). The pace is probably slow for modern audiences, but Richards is being true to the book and the era.Executive Producer Jerry Bruckheimer (1945) is the powerhouse behind so many mega hits in film and TV it's impossible to list them all. Here's a list of my top 10 - "CSI" (2000-2011), "Cold Case" (2003-10), "Without a Trace" (2002-9), "Pirates of the Caribbean" (2003), "Black Hawk Down" (2001), Armageddon" (1998), "The Rock" (1996), "Bad Boys" (1995), and "Crimson Tide" (1995). Bruckheimer's first 4 films as an associate producer/producer were with Dick Richards on "Culpepper Cattle Co." (1972), "Rafferty and the Gold Dust Twins" (1975), "Farewell My Lovely" (1975), and "March or Die" (1977).John Alonzo (1934-2001) provides the photography which captures the period very effectively. Alonzo was nominated for an Oscar and a BAFTA for "Chinatown" (1974) and won an Emmy for "Fail Safe" (2000). His short "The Legend of Jimmy Blue Eyes" won an Oscar in 1965.FWIW - The film is in color, and I think it would have been better in B&W.;David Shire provides an excellent musical score. Shire was Oscar nominated for "The Promise" (1979) and won for "Norma Rae" (1979). He received 5 Emmy nominations but no wins, and a Golden Globe nomination for "Saturday Night Fever" (1977).The film received mixed reviews. Variety called it "lethargic, vaguely campy" and said it "fails to generate much suspense or excitement". OTOH Roger Ebert was enthusiastic saying "in the genre itself there hasn't been anything this good since Hollywood was doing Philip Marlowe the first time around."The film sticks pretty close to the book, but it does underplay the sexism and racism in the book even though it is more apparent in this film than in the 1944 version.The top grossing films in 1975 were "Jaws", "The Rocky Horror Picture Show", "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", "Dog Day Afternoon", and "Shampoo"  The big Oscar winner was "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" (Picture, Director. Actor, Actress, Screenplay). Other notable films that year were "Nashville", "Taxi Driver", "Barry Lyndon", "Monty Python and the Holy Grail", and "Seven Beauties".Detective films were popular in the 70s. "Dirty Harry" started in 1971 and sequels appeared in 1973 and 76. "The French Connection" was the Oscar winner in 1971 and its sequel came out in 1975. "Chinatown" was a smash hit in 1974. "The Pink Panther" re-surfaced in 1974 and again in 1976. Other notable detective films included "Klute" (1971), "Sleuth" (1972), "The Long Goodbye" (1973), "The Conversation" (1974), "The Drowning Pool" (1975) and "Night Moves" (1975).I'm not sure you can call this an example of "film noir" as many reviewers do. Classic film noir involves the protagonist in the plot and in this film Marlowe is more of an observer and narrator rather than a participant. The central character, from a noir POV is Moose, who is the person betrayed and for whom the outcome is less than satisfactory. The seedy characters revolve around Moose and his former life. By focusing on the character of the detective, the film moves more into the classic detective/mystery genre rather than the film noir genre. In addition, the color film and the lack of the expressionistic film angles suggest we are not looking at classic film noir.Bottom line - If you're a fan of Chandler and/or remakes of 40s noir films, this is one to add to your list.

reviewText: L.A. of June 1941 as it was depicted in the Raymond Chandler's novel of the same title is filled with the dark secrets of the past that better stay uncovered. Philip Marlow, PE (Robert Mitcum) takes a job to find a vanished girlfriend of the felon Moose Malloy, and he has no idea what will follow. As Marlow searches for Velma Galento, he has to deal with a beautiful but cold and calculating seductress (Charlotte Rampling - young, sensual and dangerous), a jealous corrupt detective (Stanton), an old alcoholic girlfriend (Sylvia Miles in one of her two Oscar nominated performances, second - the shortest in the history of Oscars, for "Midnight Cowboy"), and a buffed thug (Sylvester Stallone -- it was fun to see him before he became a star of Rocky and Rambo).This adaptation of Raymond Chandler novel features action, suspense, humor, mystery and Robert Mitchum in one of his best performances as a man struggling with cynicism, hatred, and betrayal.
summary: They don't make films like that anymore

reviewText: To many of the reviews I've read rave on about Ms. Rampling, and while she is good in her small role, this is a Robert Mitchum Movie, and he is very good in it.....Actually, if it was B&W you'd look at it like an old Bogie film like "The Big Sleep",or any one of a dozen classic detective flix.....Anyway, I happen to get my hands on one of the rare DVD's and it was in great shape.  But it's the story...this is one of those films you get to watch 5 times before you actually follow everything that's going on......I truly enjoyed it, and you will too.

reviewText: Apparently, many people regard this movie as a classic.  I loved it when I first saw it.Then I saw the original ("Murder My Sweet").When you watch the two back to back, you realize how inferior the remake is.  Mainly, some of the great lines of the original are inserted out of place,  adjusted slightly  causing them to lose  their timing and relevance, or simply without the pop of the original.The pacing of the original  is non-stop. "Farewell" drags almost as much as Mitchum's  somnambulent performance.Other reviewers have raved about Mitchum's Marlowe. But that's only because Mitchum WAS Marlowe - no acting required. He was already well into that portion of his career where  his only concern was the paycheck, and this performance shows it.His sole comment about this movie -  "I had to wear Victor Mature's old f-rted up trenchcoat through the whole thing."Mitchum and Bogart are my 2nd and 3rd favorite actors of all time (#1 - Cagney.)  But Dick Powell, shockingly, was the best Marlowe - hard boiled, cut rate, sardonic, fatalistic.A  sampling of vintage lines from the original:Marlowe (describing Mrs. Florian) - "She  was a charming  middle aged lady with a face like a bucket of mud.  I offered her a drink. She was the kind of gal who would take a drink even if she had to knock you down to get the bottle."Mrs. Grayle:  "What you do at night when you're not being a detective?"Marlowe: "Lately I've been playing button-button with the cops."Marlowe (to himself): "Okay, Marlowe, you're a tough guy.  Now let's see you do something really difficult:  Put on your pants."Detective Randall to Marlowe:  "You're not a detective; you're a slot machine. You'd slit your own throat for six bits plus tax."Nothing like this in the remake.Yes, Mitchum is perfect as the aging, world weary, cynical private eye.  But that's because in 1974, Mitchum was an aging, world weary, cynical actor.Don't get me wrong - this movie is a must for collectors of film noir and absolutely should be re-released. It's fascinating to see them try to recreate 40's noir in the mod 70's, and it's always a joy to watch Mitchum even when he's doing nothing more than just reading his lines (as he is here).But don't confuse it with the FAR superior "Murder My Sweet," which, by the way, was given that title because the studio execs were afraid that the public would assume that "Farewell My Lovely" was just  another song-and-dance vehicle for Dick Powell.
summary: She was a charming  middle aged lady with a face like a bucket of mud.

reviewText: If you know the story it doesn't matter. The moody noir atmosphere is everything in this film. It is the type of movie that can be viewed multiple times. The acting by the veteran actors are authentic for the period. The pacing is right on target and viewing this picture is like going back in a time machine. It captures a time and place in L.A. of the early forties and the story proceeds without any pretense or glamor. They must re-release this film at all costs.
summary: Lots of dark scenes in old L.A.

reviewText: Robert Mitchum's latter day masterpiece.  He IS Phillip Marlow in this darkly humorous and sometimes violent adaption of Raymond Chandler's great novel.  Mitchum does not phone in his performance but was really in to the role.  Speaking of the role Charlotte Rampling plays as he walks behind her, Mitchum says "She was giving me a look I could feel all the way in my hip pocket."  Marvelous.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Fans of film noir movies should see this. Robert Mitchum is the king of the film noir genre, and while it is easy enough to buy some of his classics, such as "Out of the Past" and "The Night of the Hunter", this film is rare and expensive, particularly if you want it as a region one DVD.Mitchum made this film some 20 years after the height of his career as a leading man in this kind of film, but he is still a powerful figure as Raymond Chandler's tough-guy detective Philip Marlowe. World-weary and tired, Mitchum is still a charismatic figure in the film.This movie is actually an adaptation of Chandler's "Murder My Sweet," which was also adapted more than 30 years earlier under its original title.It is a typically gritty story of heartbreak and murder set in old Los Angeles. The convoluted plot riddled with dead-ends is also typical of Chandler. This is a very well done film noir detective story.
summary: A rare copy of a film noir classic

reviewText: I am now trying to purchase this movie, it looks like I can only get it in used VHS form. (I cant wait any longer for it on DVD, but will definately buy it again when it is available on DVD WS).But I will forever remember this movie as a young teen, sitting in the theatre, when it first came out in the 1970's. I sat and watched it over and over and over again! I've always loved Robert Mitchum, always loved Film Noir and this Movie has it all. Mitchum was a great actor and this is by far his greatest role, his greatest acting in his long career. The acting, the cinematography, the music, all great! Yes, lots of previous versions from the 30's, etc which were also good, but this one is NOT good, it is GREAT! This could have been and has the exact great look of a 30's, 40's, 50's noir. I cant say enough about this flick, so I'll stop now! If you like film noir, Robert mitchum, mysteries, an excellent movie, then you've got to see this one. Not only see it, but experience it!

reviewText: This film is a remake of Murder My Sweet with Dick Powell.  The earlier version is in black and white and very 40's in its approach.  Farewell My Lovely is in color and though it tries to capture the old film noir  feeling, it is a touch more cynical and modern.  Nevertheless it is a fine  rendition.  It is hard to choose between the two versions as each has its  individual charm.Robert Mitchum is older and heavier than my mental  picture of Phillip Marlowe, but he brings convincing gravitas to the role.  Charlotte Rampling is at her most delectable self.  The supporting roles  are extremely well done.  The music definitely adds to the atmosphere.Some of my friends found the plot too complex to follow.  I found this  to be an asset and part of the essence of the genre.  While not quite in  the league of a masterpiece like Chinatown, this film holds its own with  such modern approximations of film noir like LA Confidential.  Turn to  Double Indemnity, The Big Sleep, and To Have and Have Not for the real  thing.  Meanwhile, you can confidently enjoy this movie too.
summary: Excellent, but not quite a masterpiece.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First off, I know and understand fully that there exists a certain fragment of the population the loves Robert Mitchum and everything he's done, this included and this especially.I've listened to people tell me that Mitchum was the quintessential Philip Marlowe.  While I never examined that statement fully until now, I never bucked it. But something definitely has to be said. Robert Mitchum was no Bogart and definitely no Philip Marlowe.This movie was a travesty and a poor execution in any genre of film making. I hate to rock the boat and hold the minority report, if I do, but this film would likely anger Raymond Chandler to no end and it stands as everything wrong with an adaptation and is a horrible interpretation of his classic novel. It takes so many liberties, if I was in charge of his estate, I would have likely have sued these people.So many liberties were taken to the point that several things in this movie were just complete ad-hoc fabrications pulled  out of thin air. Honestly, there is no reason for that at all.Second, instead of just leaving a lot of the dialogue alone and inserting it into the film appropriately, the dialogue finds its way in awkwardly, in ham-handed bits and pieces by Mitchum. Chandler's strength was his descriptive and incredibly powerful dialogue as was his ability to craft quiet scenes instead of always having to be action heavy.The liberties taken with the story are unforgivable as so many things were done to adjust a very basic Detective yarn which is action packed from beginning to end and turning it into something sappy and trite. It's almost as if the writers and producers of this mess, said let's take everything right that Bogart did and throw it all out the window and make stuff up while we're at it.After looking around, I discovered how difficult it is to get this on a Region 1 DVD for US viewing, after watching this wreck twice, I can see why no one wants to distribute it. Here's hoping someone remakes the entire Marlowe series in my life time, true to era.This film will soon fall completely out of distribution and will be thankfully forgotten. Shame. Someone please call Raymond Chandler and tell him to slap Robert Mitchum if he sees him.
summary: Chandler would have punched the wall ...
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Farewell My Lovely," based on the novel of the same name by famed hard-boiled detective author Raymond Chandler, a Californian,(Farewell, My Lovely),is set in the author's glamorous 1940's film noir Los Angeles.  However, it was filmed, lavishly -- no stinting on any car or landmark -- in the Los Angeles of the 1970's, to be released in 1975.  It was also filmed in color, the theory being that LA noirs may successfully be filmed in color.  1970's LA was then rather neo-noir itself, in the sour aftermath of the Manson family murders, and the Hell's Angels' murder at the Rolling Stones' Altamont concert.  Quite a few neo-noirs were being filmed there and then, in color.  "Farewell" is actually an English production.  David Selag Goodman adapted the script, staying much closer to the novel than the original, 1944 adaptation,(Murder, My Sweet), starring Dick Powell.  Jerry Bruckheimer gets a production credit on the movie; his touch might be seen in the open-handedness with which it's filmed, the well-orchestrated, swift-moving scenes of violence -- the whole movie clocks in at a quick 98 minutes-- and the all-star cast assembled for it.The movie evokes its time: Joe DiMaggio's breathlessly followed 1941 hitting streak.  And it succeeds in giving us a sense that December 7, 1941 is inevitably coming: "The day that will live in infamy," then President Roosevelt famously said.  The day that began World War II, with the Japanese dawn bombing of Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, ( that's not so far from LA).  The jazzy score is by David Shire.  The cinematography was by John Alonzo, who had just doneChinatown (Special Collector's Edition), the year before; he gives us a real sense of the sun baked, beautiful but sinister city of its setting.This film should be sufficient to convince anyone that Robert Mitchum was born to play Philip Marlowe.  Even though it's true that, in his late 50's at the time, he was a bit old for it.  Never mind, that lived-in, world weary, expressive face, with a hint of humor in the heavy-lidded eyes, and the tough old guy body language, is perfect for the role.  And Chandler told interviewers he'd visualized Mitchum for the part all along.  Mitchum is ably supported by the ever cool, gorgeously sultry Charlotte Rampling as the femme fatale.  The cast also includes John Ireland, Sylvia Miles, Anthony Zerbe, Harry Dean Stanton, and a young Sylvester Stallone, in an important, though hardly speaking, bit part.Things open as a down on his luck Marlowe:" All I own is a hat, a gun, and a suit," he says, is approached by a new, would-be client, giant Moose Malloy, fresh from prison after doing seven years for his girlfriend Velma (Rampling).  She's cute as "lace-trimmed pants," the ex-con says, and he wants Marlowe to find her.  That investigation will take Marlowe through the highlife, and lowlifes of LA.  He'll end up no better off than he was, in fact, the worse for wear.  But people he meets on his quest are going to end up even worse.This is a strong, well-done movie, with an interesting, complex plot.  It certainly can stand aside the earlier, black and white classic version.
summary: It Can Stand Alongside The Earlier Version
Title: N/A

reviewText: The photography is perfect, the score is magnificent.  Robert Mitchum was made to play a middle aged Philip Marlowe, and his voice over has all the weariness and angst the most die hard noir fan could ask for.  The mid-30's sets are impeccable.  So what is there to complain about?  I think the culprit is Raymond Chandler.One of the most quotable of the hard-boiled writers, his writing sang but his plots were so convoluted, the reader needs a scorecard to keep track of the story. Marlowe is hired by ex-con Moose Malloy to find his elusive love Velma.  Until the bloody finale, that was the last time I was clear about the action.I commend all the actors for delivering fine performances, particularly Sylvia Myles who played the hopeless alcoholic, Mrs. Florian.  She was piercingly pathetic as a nice girl who couldn't quite believe she was a middle-aged drunk.  Robert Mitchum allowed merciless lighting that occasionally made him look like a guy who has had one too many face-lifts.This film version of "Farewell My Lovely" is probably as good as it gets.  I recommend "Out of the Past" for Mitchum and noir fans.-sweetmolly-Amazon Reviewer
